SHERIFF'S SALES.
BY PETER B. DELANY. SHERIFF.

Washington, February 6 A new and very un.
welcome topic was yesterday introduced iR.o both
Houses Of Congress- by the Message Of the Pres.
dent Of The United States, touching the question
which has arisen between the United States and the
State Of Georgia, in regard TO the execution OF the
las, Treaty with the Creek Indians. Though we
are sure that nothing serious will be allowed to re
suit from it, it is not without great regret that we
have the collision arrive even at The point
which it has reached. The subject is one which
demands the serious and, above all, the dispassion
ATE. consideration OF the Public Councils Any
her treatment Of it--any other result than good
understanding between the STATE and General Gov
einmtns, odut ed bv mutual forbearsnce aud good
ieeng--wii exhibit this country TO the world in an
attitudr j, has never before assumed and ct mo-
mtpt when, more Than ever, we should. in cherish
M the peace and harmony of our Union, entitle
ourselves to the respect Of our friends even Of and
our enemies abroad


Tu}oIIirsncer

The reader is referred to The Message Of the Pres
iden,, in another column. Whilst every good cti-
zen must regret that any Misunderstanding should
exs, between the general government and that Of
any OF the States, the tone OF the Message is such
cannot iai, we think, to meet the appreciation OF
nine tenhs Of the people OF the United States. who
we are persuaded, whatever objections they may
have to the Administration will uphold it in The de-
ience Of honor and justice.

FROM ST. DOMlNGO.-CaptO Oliver, Of the
schooner Maria, arrived las, evening from Baracos,
states that the Governor of Baracoa received the
day before he lett there despatch from ST. Jago,
informing that the French Consul had arrived there
from ST Domingo, who stated ihs. revolution had
broke out in the island between the blacks and null
a,toes, and tha. the latter had collected in large
bodies.

A writer who calls himself "A Republican Of
Delaware" in the U. S. Telegraph. published at
Washington City, expatates largely ON Mr. M
Lanes love OF country, and evidence OF it, he
sets forth, in glowing colors, the simple circumstance
that Mr.. M'Lane belonged to artillery corps In
this Borough during the last war, and thai he march
ed to the defence OF Baltimore, sc &C. The whole
history OF this matter is, MIR M'Lane, in company
with hundreds o! his townsmen, marched to Elkton
| and then marched back again. and here his military
services ended-and we are persuaded tina, his feel
ings will be mortified at seeing the attempt that is
made to magnify that act Of duty into proof OF his
extraordinary patriotism.

We learn, says the Boston Palladium, OF Friday
last, by a gentleman who came in last nights East
ern Stage. that the Senate Of Maine has ooncurred
with the House in the election of Governor Parris,
to the National Senate.


From the State Of Mississippi, we learn, that an
election for Senator of the United States, to sue
| ceed Mr.. Reed took place on the 4lh uhimo and
that PoWhatan Eitis was chosen, for the term Of
six years from the third day Of March next, when
the term of Mr.. Reed will expire. The vote, in
Joint ballot Of the two branches OF the Legislature
was, for Mr.. Ellis, s7 votes; Tor Mr.. Reed, l6
| votes.

porter Of about $4,000, 1t is supposed that he had
a false key TO the vault.

Mr. Ferguson. came stranger to my
.ou.e on tho 18th or 18th ct December last-he
,ald his name was Garret Sap says he has a broth
in Salem county and two children in the state of
Delaware-he was taken sick the next Sabbath and
died the Sabbath following every attention was
paid him during his sickness that could be, and he
was decen,iy buried 10 the Presbyterian Buryng
Ground, al the Indian Fields Further particulars
will be made knows by me, at the Beaver Dam
Tavern, between Brdgeton and hllvile.

portion oil The Union from znother.', WASHINGTON.

TIMOTHY PirK1N Esq. Of Connecticut, (former-
" for many years prominent member of Congress,
and author OF we'll known work on the Statistics
Of he Union,) has issued proposals for a work en-
tled Sketches OF the Political and Civil History
ii the United States" from the settlement OF the
Colonies 10 the close Of The Administration of Prcs


denr Washington to be comprised in two volumes,
Of 500 pages each, a, 81 so per volume. One OF
The objects of Mr.. p in this work, is to trace the
origin Of our political and civil institutions. aud the
more remote, as we'll as proxmate, causes of our
Revolution. From on attentive investigation Of the
Colonial disputes with the parent country and par


cularly that arising from the monopoly Of the com
merce and manufactures OF the Colonists Mr.. r.
is led to the conclusion that the seeds Of the Revolu


ton were sown long before the passage OF The Stamp
Act Any additional light on this part of our his


tory will be valuable and from the papers OF ndivl.
duals to which we understand Mr.. p. has had &C.
cess he expects to b. able to present some interes-


ting facts particularly in relation to our Foreign Al.
fairs during the Revolution, not generally known.
We are confident that MIR. P. will carefully exclude
every thing Of party character from his work and
as we know not many hands better qualified for such
a task we anticipate from his abors ar important

Washington, February 6 A new and very un.
welcome topic was yesterday introduced iR.o both
Houses Of Congress- by the Message Of the Pres.
dent Of The United States, touching the question
which has arisen between the United States and the
State Of Georgia, in regard TO the execution OF the
las, Treaty with the Creek Indians. Though we
are sure that nothing serious will be allowed to re
suit from it, it is not without great regret that we
have the collision arrive even at The point
which it has reached. The subject is one which
demands the serious and, above all, the dispassion
ATE. consideration OF the Public Councils Any
her treatment Of it--any other result than good
understanding between the STATE and General Gov
einmtns, odut ed bv mutual forbearsnce aud good
ieeng--wii exhibit this country TO the world in an
attitudr j, has never before assumed and ct mo-
mtpt when, more Than ever, we should. in cherish
M the peace and harmony of our Union, entitle
ourselves to the respect Of our friends even Of and
our enemies abroad


Tu}oIIirsncer

The reader is referred to The Message Of the Pres
iden,, in another column. Whilst every good cti-
zen must regret that any Misunderstanding should
exs, between the general government and that Of
any OF the States, the tone OF the Message is such
cannot iai, we think, to meet the appreciation OF
nine tenhs Of the people OF the United States. who
we are persuaded, whatever objections they may
have to the Administration will uphold it in The de-
ience Of honor and justice.

FROM ST. DOMlNGO.-CaptO Oliver, Of the
schooner Maria, arrived las, evening from Baracos,
states that the Governor of Baracoa received the
day before he lett there despatch from ST. Jago,
informing that the French Consul had arrived there
from ST Domingo, who stated ihs. revolution had
broke out in the island between the blacks and null
a,toes, and tha. the latter had collected in large
bodies.

A writer who calls himself "A Republican Of
Delaware" in the U. S. Telegraph. published at
Washington City, expatates largely ON Mr. M
Lanes love OF country, and evidence OF it, he
sets forth, in glowing colors, the simple circumstance
that Mr.. M'Lane belonged to artillery corps In
this Borough during the last war, and thai he march
ed to the defence OF Baltimore, sc &C. The whole
history OF this matter is, MIR M'Lane, in company
with hundreds o! his townsmen, marched to Elkton
| and then marched back again. and here his military
services ended-and we are persuaded tina, his feel
ings will be mortified at seeing the attempt that is
made to magnify that act Of duty into proof OF his
extraordinary patriotism.

Of the most respectable families in town, testify
their appreciation OF the establishment, by purchas
ing soup for their own use.'

SENATOR FOR MAINE.
We learn, says the Boston Palladium, OF Friday
last, by a gentleman who came in last nights East
ern Stage. that the Senate Of Maine has ooncurred
with the House in the election of Governor Parris,
to the National Senate.


From the State Of Mississippi, we learn, that an
election for Senator of the United States, to sue
| ceed Mr.. Reed took place on the 4lh uhimo and
that PoWhatan Eitis was chosen, for the term Of
six years from the third day Of March next, when
the term of Mr.. Reed will expire. The vote, in
Joint ballot Of the two branches OF the Legislature
was, for Mr.. Ellis, s7 votes; Tor Mr.. Reed, l6
| votes.


The Bank Of Kentucky has been robbed by its
porter Of about $4,000, 1t is supposed that he had
a false key TO the vault.

Consumpfons. The New York Times states that the
deaths in that city by Consumption during the last ten
years. were 6646, nearly oneh Of the whole number
Of deaths Ia publishing this fact the editor justly re-

most sweeping rayages among those who in the very

Mr. Ferguson. came stranger to my
.ou.e on tho 18th or 18th ct December last-he
,ald his name was Garret Sap says he has a broth
in Salem county and two children in the state of
Delaware-he was taken sick the next Sabbath and
died the Sabbath following every attention was
paid him during his sickness that could be, and he
was decen,iy buried 10 the Presbyterian Buryng
Ground, al the Indian Fields Further particulars
will be made knows by me, at the Beaver Dam
Tavern, between Brdgeton and hllvile.


MARK BOWEN.
January 29th, 1927


N. b. The Salem Messenger and the papers Of
The state OF Delaware, will serve the cause OF hu-
manty by publishing the above.

Frowa ndgnantyupon the dawnng attempt aicnat
portion oil The Union from znother.', WASHINGTON.

TIMOTHY PirK1N Esq. Of Connecticut, (former-
" for many years prominent member of Congress,
and author OF we'll known work on the Statistics
Of he Union,) has issued proposals for a work en-
tled Sketches OF the Political and Civil History
ii the United States" from the settlement OF the
Colonies 10 the close Of The Administration of Prcs


denr Washington to be comprised in two volumes,
Of 500 pages each, a, 81 so per volume. One OF
The objects of Mr.. p in this work, is to trace the
origin Of our political and civil institutions. aud the
more remote, as we'll as proxmate, causes of our
Revolution. From on attentive investigation Of the
Colonial disputes with the parent country and par


cularly that arising from the monopoly Of the com
merce and manufactures OF the Colonists Mr.. r.
is led to the conclusion that the seeds Of the Revolu


ton were sown long before the passage OF The Stamp
Act Any additional light on this part of our his


tory will be valuable and from the papers OF ndivl.
duals to which we understand Mr.. p. has had &C.
cess he expects to b. able to present some interes-


ting facts particularly in relation to our Foreign Al.
fairs during the Revolution, not generally known.
We are confident that MIR. P. will carefully exclude
every thing Of party character from his work and
as we know not many hands better qualified for such
a task we anticipate from his abors ar important
